femtograd 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

    • femtograd-intro

    femtograd-intro

    femtograd-intro.Rmd
    library(femtograd)

    Let’s create a simple loglikelihood function for the exponential distribution paramterized by \(\lambda\) (failure rate).

    We have \[ f_{T_i}(t_i | \lambda) = \lambda \exp(-\lambda t_i). \] So, the loglikelihood function is just \[ \ell(\lambda) = n \log \lambda - \lambda \sum_{i=1}^n t_i. \]

    Let’s generate \(n=100\) observations.

    n <- 100
rate <- val(1)
data <- rexp(n,rate$data)
score <- n / rate$data - sum(data)
head(data)
#> [1] 1.36528204 0.49453333 1.49549601 0.15057316 0.85732022 0.07863417

cat("loglike =", n * log(rate$data) - rate$data * sum(data), "\n")
#> loglike = -105.5554
cat("rate =", rate$data, "\n")
#> rate = 1
cat("score =", score, "\n")
#> score = -5.555444

    We see that at \(\hat\lambda = 1\), the score is \(-5.5554439\). Let’s use femtograd package to construct the log-likelihood function.

    loglike_exp <- function(rate, data)
  val(length(data)) * log(rate) - rate * sum(data)  

loglik <- loglike_exp(rate, data)
zero_grad(loglik)
backward(loglik)
cat("loglike =", loglik$data, "\n")
#> loglike = -105.5554
cat("rate = ", rate$data, "\n")
#> rate =  1
cat("dloglik/drate =", rate$grad, "\n")
#> dloglik/drate = -5.555444

    We see that the score is \(-5.5554439\), which agreeds with the previous calculation. Now, let’s set \(\hat\lambda\) to \(1/\bar{t}\), the MLE.

    rate <- val(1/mean(data))
loglik <- loglike_exp(rate, data)
zero_grad(loglik)
backward(loglik)
cat("loglike =", loglik$data, "\n")
#> loglike = -105.4066
cat("rate = ", rate$data, "\n")
#> rate =  0.9473694
cat("dloglik/drate =", rate$grad, "\n")
#> dloglik/drate = -1.421085e-14

    As expected, we see that the score is \(-1.4210855\times 10^{-14}\) (zero). Also, the log-likelihood is larger (should be maximum) at this rate value.

    Next, we show how to find the MLE using a simple iteration. First, we set \(\hat\lambda\) to \(5\), a terrible estimate.

    rate <- val(5)

    Now we loop 20 times.

    for (i in 1:20)
{
  loglik <- loglike_exp(rate, data)
  zero_grad(loglik)
  backward(loglik)
  rate <- val(rate$data + 0.01 * rate$grad)
  cat("rate =", rate$data, "\n")
}
#> rate = 4.144446 
#> rate = 3.330178 
#> rate = 2.574908 
#> rate = 1.907717 
#> rate = 1.376349 
#> rate = 1.047355 
#> rate = 0.9465866 
#> rate = 0.9474595 
#> rate = 0.9473591 
#> rate = 0.9473706 
#> rate = 0.9473693 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694 
#> rate = 0.9473694

    Did it converge to the MLE?

    print(abs(1/mean(data) - rate$data) < 1e-3)
#> [1] TRUE

    It appears so.
